comments:
As a Wharton undergraduate, students are in a position to become a future business
leader. Management 100 is designed to increase students’ understanding of leadership
and communication in teams to help students build skills that are necessary for
professional success. Students study literature on leadership, management
communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of
the course. Field projects provide the context in which students develop as leaders,
practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance their
sensitivity to community issues.
While students did comment that a lot of time was spent on their MGMT 100
projects, students commented that they were “able to see the tremendous value that
MGMT 100 has.” Other students commented that MGMT 100 was “amazing and
educational.” One student commented that this course was their “best course this
semester!”
Students only had good things to say about Professor Greenhalgh, also known as
“Dr. G.” Many students described her as “amazing” and “an inspirational and tremendous
instructor.” She was constantly described as a great lecturer and “clearly passionate about
the subject material.” Students also stated that Dr. G. tried to form relationships with her
many students and was pretty successful in this large feat.
This course is required for all Wharton undergraduates. Freshmen are placed into
the Fall semester sections of MGMT 100. The workload for this course is heavy, since
the projects for this course require tremendous time commitments.

Management 100 is designed to increase your understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help you build skills that are necessary for professional success, because, as a Wharton undergraduate, you are in a position to become a future business leader. You will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project- an integral part of the course. Your field project provides the context in which you will develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance your sensitivity to community issues. Management 100 will enrich your Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community.

Opinions were split regarding the content of Management 100.  Some students found the content of this class to be “useless” and “repetitive,” with one student at the end of the semester stating: “I still don’t understand why this course was necessary.”  Another student explains that the content simply involved “busy-work and pointless surveys.” Many students saw some disconnect between lecture content and the actual team projects.  Others found the class was “a refreshing break from quantitative courses” and one of “the most hands-on courses” offered at Penn.  For one student, this course provided her with an “opportunity to form relationships” with fellow cohort members.  Another student noted that he was “able to practice teamwork skills” and “public speaking.”  Many students found the course readings “applicable,” but also “redundant.”  One student believed the course was “definitely the most time-consuming course to take as a freshman.”  Another summed the course up as one that “truly depends on your team and yourself.”

Few students commented directly about Professor Maxwell’s teaching ability. One student found that despite the emphasis on “feedback” throughout the entire course, “there was very little of it” and it was difficult to understand exactly what the professor was looking for.  Another student notes that Professor Maxwell was “helpful,” although the lectures seemed “to be out of touch with recitations and the overall project at times.” 

The grading is described as “extremely subjective” by one student and most agree that having curved grades within teams “encourages teams to mark each other down” and causes undue anxiety.  A majority of students found that the “grading system in this class was not representative of how you do.”  One student echoes that sentiment to state that “it is difficult to gauge or estimate your grade, as most of it is subjective.” Some students believed that this course has an “excessive” workload.  It is a required course for all students pursuing a degree in the Wharton School.

Management 100 is designed to increase your understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help you build skills that are necessary for professional success, because, as a Wharton undergraduate, you are in a position to become a future business leader. You will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project- an integral part of the course. Your field project provides the context in which you will develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance your sensitivity to community issues. Management 100 will enrich your Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community.

Opinions were split regarding the content of Management 100.  Some students found the content of this class to be “useless” and “repetitive,” with one student at the end of the semester stating: “I still don’t understand why this course was necessary.”  Another student explains that the content simply involved “busy-work and pointless surveys.” Many students saw some disconnect between lecture content and the actual team projects.  Others found the class was “a refreshing break from quantitative courses” and one of “the most hands-on courses” offered at Penn.  For one student, this course provided her with an “opportunity to form relationships” with fellow cohort members.  Another student noted that he was “able to practice teamwork skills” and “public speaking.”  Many students found the course readings “applicable,” but also “redundant.”  One student believed the course was “definitely the most time-consuming course to take as a freshman.”  Another summed the course up as one that “truly depends on your team and yourself.”

A majority of students had positive reviews for Professor Myers.  Professor Myers was called “an amazing teacher” who “excels at being able to convey the material in a way that makes sense.”  One student said that Professor Myers was an “excellent, pragmatic professor” who “brought humor into the class” and tried “her best to make a terrible course slightly better.”  Another student stated that Professor Myers “shows a genuine interest in every single student” and “wants everyone to do well.”  One student thought Professor Myers was very “knowledgeable,” “energetic,” and praised Professor Myers’ “availability to talk about course assignments or project issues.”

The grading is described as “extremely subjective” by one student and most agree that having curved grades within teams “encourages teams to mark each other down” and causes undue anxiety.  A majority of students found that the “grading system in this class was not representative of how you do.”  One student echoes that sentiment to state that “it is difficult to gauge or estimate your grade, as most of it is subjective.” Some students believed that this course has an “excessive” workload.  It is a required course for all students pursuing a degree in the Wharton School.

Management 100 is designed to increase students' understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help build skills that are necessary for professional success. Students will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. The field project provides the context in which students will develop as leaders, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance sensitivity to community issues. This course provides opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community. 
 
While students did comment that a lot of time was spent on their MGMT 100 projects, students agreed that they were “able to see the tremendous value that MGMT 100 has.” Other students commented that MGMT 100 was “amazing and educational.” One student claimed that this course was their “best course this semester!”

Students had only good things to say about Professor Greenhalgh, also known as “Dr. G.” Many students described her as “amazing” and “an inspirational and tremendous instructor.” She was constantly described as a great lecturer and was “clearly passionate about the subject material.” Students also stated that Dr. G. tried to form relationships with her many students and was very successful in this large feat. 

This course is required for all Wharton undergraduates. Freshmen are placed into the fall semester sections of MGMT 100. The workload for this course is heavy, since the projects for this course require tremendous time commitments.

Management 100 is designed to increase students' understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help build skills that are necessary for professional success. Students will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. The field project provides the context in which students will develop as leaders, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance sensitivity to community issues. This course provides opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community. 

Some students thought the readings were very theoretical and hard to apply. However, students learned how to work together and about the roles people play within a project. The activities were hands-on and engaging. 

Professor Maxwell was very accessible, but was unclear in his expectations for assignments. He was a very "engaging and enjoyable" lecturer.

Students thought the grading was very subjective, with "no clear rubrics." The in-class assignments were time-consuming. The largest complaint of this course was that the material was impractical and could have been condensed to reduce the time commitment.

Management 100 is designed to increase your understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help you build skills that are necessary for professional success.  You will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course.  Your field project provides the context in which you will develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance your sensitivity to community issues.  This course will enrich the Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community. 

Students said the course was useful “in developing teamwork and leadership skills.”  One student said the course “is a cornerstone and very important component” in a Wharton undergraduate’s studies, though there are areas where it can be improved.  The class is not academic-oriented.  It requires a good amount of teamwork, but students felt it left them with new thoughts after “working with a randomly assigned group.”  The students claimed that it teaches the importance of “feedforward, constructive brainstorming and teamwork building to overcome obstacles.”

Most students had positive reviews about Professor Myers.  She did an “excellent job explaining management theory and its relevance to our team projects.”  One student said she was an “all-around enjoyable person” and could see her passion for the material. Another mentioned that they “really looked forward to coming to lecture each day” because they knew Professor Myers would be “enthusiastic and engaging.” A third student commented that Professor Myers was “an active listener” who “cares deeply about each and every student.”

One student suggested that the workload be “spread out over the course instead of concentrated at particular intervals.”  The course requires a lot of work “outside of the class.” All students, freshman, transfer students, and dual degree students must complete MGMT 100.
